review.title: Data-driven Rank Breaking for Efficient Rank Aggregation
review.abstract: Rank aggregation systems collect ordinal preferences from individuals to produce a global ranking that represents the social preference. Rank-breaking is a common practice to reduce the computational complexity of learning the global ranking. The individual preferences are broken into pairwise comparisons and applied to efficient algorithms tailored for independent paired comparisons. However, due to the ignored dependencies in the data, naive rank-breaking approaches can result in inconsistent estimates. The key idea to produce accurate and unbiased estimates is to treat the pairwise comparisons unequally, depending on the topology of the collected data. In this paper, we provide the optimal rank-breaking estimator, which not only achieves consistency but also achieves the best error bound. This allows us to characterize the fundamental tradeoff between accuracy and complexity. Further, the analysis identifies how the accuracy depends on the spectral gap of a corresponding comparison graph.

sections.heading: 4 The Role of the Topology of the Data
sections.text: We examine the role of the topology of data, which guides the design of data collection when we have some control, such as recommendation systems, surveys and crowdsourcing. The central optimization problem that is of interest to the developer of such a system is to achieve the best accuracy while minimizing the number of questions.

sections.heading: 4.1 The Role of the Graph Laplacian
sections.text: We use the same number of samples, comparison graphs with larger spectral gaps achieve better accuracy compared to those with smaller spectral gaps. To illustrate how graph topology affects accuracy, we produce known spectral properties of canonical graphs and numerically compare the performance of data-driven ranking breaks for multiple graph topologies. We follow the examples and experimental graphs of [52] for a similar result with random comparisons. Spectral properties of graphs have been a topic of wide interest for decades. We consider a scenario in which we fix the size of the offers as κj = O (1) and each agent provides a partial ranking with "separators whose positions are chosen uniformly at random. So we take generated results as a baseline truth and compare the performance of the data-driven ranking of the GMM approach.

sections.heading: 7 Discussion
sections.text: We study the problem of learning the PL model using ordinals. In traditional data collection scenarios, several efficient algorithms find the maximum probability estimate while demonstrably achieving the minimum optimal performance. However, in some non-traditional scenarios, the computational complexity of determining the maximum probability estimate in the problem size can be scaled superexponentially. We provide the first finite sample analysis of computationally efficient estimators, the so-called rank-refracting estimators. This provides guidelines for selecting weights in the estimator to achieve optimal performance, and also explicitly shows how accuracy depends on the topology of the data. This paper provides the first analytical result in the sample complexity of rank-refracting estimators and quantifies the price we pay for the accuracy of the computational gain. In general, more complex cross-ranking breaks can also be taken into account, where instead of a partial sequence of rank comparisons is divided into higher order.

metadata.abstractText: Rank aggregation systems collect ordinal preferences from individuals to produce a global ranking that represents the social preference. Rank-breaking is a common practice to reduce the computational complexity of learning the global ranking. The individual preferences are broken into pairwise comparisons and applied to efficient algorithms tailored for independent paired comparisons. However, due to the ignored dependencies in the data, naive rank-breaking approaches can result in inconsistent estimates. The key idea to produce accurate and consistent estimates is to treat the pairwise comparisons unequally, depending on the topology of the collected data. In this paper, we provide the optimal rank-breaking estimator, which not only achieves consistency but also achieves the best error bound. This allows us to characterize the fundamental tradeoff between accuracy and complexity. Further, the analysis identifies how the accuracy depends on the spectral gap of a corresponding comparison graph.
